info.title: Disputes
info.description:
Occasionally, something goes wrong with a customer's order. To dispute a charge, a customer can create a dispute with PayPal. PayPal merchants, partners, and external developers can use the PayPal Disputes API to manage customer disputes.
Note: In the live environment, merchants cannot create disputes but can only respond to customer-created disputes. However, merchants can create disputes in the sandbox environment. When you create an app, enable Disputes in the App feature options section.
A customer can also ask his or her bank or credit card company to dispute and reverse a charge, which is known as a chargeback. For more information, see Disputes, claims, chargebacks, and bank reversals.

When a customer disputes a charge, you can use this API to provide evidence that the charge is legitimate. To provide evidence or appeal a dispute, you submit a proof of delivery or proof of refund document or notes, which can include logs.

Normally, an agent at PayPal creates a dispute, updates the dispute status, and settles disputes, but now you can run test cases in the sandbox that complete these operations.

Important: The create, cancel, compute metrics, change reason, and validate eligibility methods are available as a limited-release solution at this time. For more information, reach out to your PayPal account manager.

For details, see Disputes Overview documentation.

This privilege allows client to update a dispute (Partner actions).

post.description:
Provides evidence for a dispute, by ID. A merchant can provide evidence for disputes with the WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE status while customers can provide evidence for disputes with the WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE status. Evidence can be a proof of delivery or proof of refund document or notes, which can include logs. A proof of delivery document includes a tracking number while a proof of refund document includes a refund ID. For other evidence type, notes and documents can be given. The following rules apply to document file types and sizes:
  • The merchant can upload up to 50 MB of files for a case.
  • Individual files must be smaller than 10 MB.
  • The supported file formats are JPG, GIF, PNG, and PDF.

To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the evidence in the JSON request body. For information about dispute reasons, see dispute reasons.

get.description:
Lists disputes with a summary set of details, which shows the dispute_id, reason, status, dispute_state, dispute_life_cycle_stage, dispute_channel, dispute_amount, create_time and update_time fields.

To filter the disputes in the response, specify one or more optional query parameters. To limit the number of disputes in the response, specify the page_size query parameter.

To list multiple disputes, set these query parameters in the request:
  • page_size=2
  • start_time instead of disputed_transaction_id

If the response contains more than two disputes, it lists two disputes and includes a HATEOAS link to the next page of results.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP 200 OK status code and a JSON response body that lists disputes with a full or summary set of details. Default is a summary set of details, which shows the dispute_id, reason, status, dispute_amount, create_time, and update_time fields for each dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

parameters.name: Authorization
parameters.description: To make REST API calls, include the bearer token in the Authorization header with the Bearer authentication scheme.

parameters.name: account_number
parameters.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a PayPal user account with this payer ID.
Note: By default, the list shows the disputes for the logged-in user who calls the API. The user invokes the API through an access token and the API fetches the disputes of the logged-in user based on this token. So, the user does not explicitly send his or her account number to the API. For partner accounts, shows details for all disputes that are related to merchants who are associated with the partner. For a MAM account, it can list disputes for a child account by account number.

parameters.name: start_time
parameters.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a creation date and time. The start time must be within the last 180 days. Value is in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

You can specify either but not both the `start_time` and `disputed_transaction_id` query parameters.

parameters.name: disputed_transaction_id
parameters.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a transaction, by ID.

You can specify either but not both the `start_time` and `disputed_transaction_id` query parameter.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the results, as a non-zero integer. Enables you to search by page number. Use in combination with the `page_size`.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Limits the number of disputes in the response to this value.

parameters.name: next_page_token
parameters.description: The token that describes the next page of results to fetch. The list disputes call returns this token in the HATEOAS links in the response.

parameters.name: total_required
parameters.description: Indicates whether to include the total number of items in the response.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Filters the fields returned for each dispute in the response to a set of summary fields or all fields. Value is `summary` or `all`. The `all` value is supported for transaction ID queries but not supported for time-range queries. The set of summary fields are `dispute_id`, `reason`, `status`, `dispute_amount`, `create_time`, and `update_time`.

parameters.name: dispute_state
parameters.description: Filters the disputes in the response by a state. Separate multiple values with a comma (`,`). When you specify more than one dispute_state, the response lists disputes that belong to any of the specified dispute_state.

x-enum.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those with the REQUIRED_ACTION dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the REQUIRED_OTHER_PARTY_ACTION dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the UNDER_PAYPAL_REVIEW dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the RESOLVED dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the OPEN_INQUIRIES dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the APPEALABLE dispute state.

parameters.name: statuses

parameters.name: create_time_before
parameters.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

parameters.name: create_time_after
parameters.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

parameters.name: update_time_before
parameters.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`. update_time_before must be within the last 180 days and the default is the current time.

parameters.name: update_time_after
parameters.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`. update_time_after must be within the last 180 days and the default is the maximum time (180 days) supported.

parameters.name: response_due_date_before
parameters.description: The date and time before which the dispute is due for response, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

parameters.name: response_due_date_after
parameters.description: The date and time after which the dispute is due for response, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

post.description:
Provides supporting information for a dispute, by ID. A merchant or buyer can make this request for disputes if they find the `provide-supporting-info` link in the HATEOAS links in the list disputes response. The party can provide the supporting information to PayPal to defend themselves only when the `dispute_life_cycle_stage` is `CHARGEBACK`, `PRE_ARBITRATION`, or `ARBITRATION`. They can provide a note that describes their part with details or upload any supporting documents to support their side. The following rules apply to document file types and sizes:
  • The party can upload up to 50 MB of files for a case.
  • Individual files must be smaller than 10 MB.
  • The supported file formats are JPG, GIF, PNG, and PDF.

To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the notes in the JSON request body. This method differs from the provide evidence method which supports only multipart request, where PayPal asks the concerned party for evidence.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

post.description:
Important: This method is for sandbox use only.
Updates the status of a dispute, by ID, from UNDER_REVIEW to either:
  • WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE
  • WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE
This status change enables either the customer or merchant to submit evidence for the dispute. To make this call, the dispute status must be UNDER_REVIEW. Specify an action value in the JSON request body to indicate whether the status change enables the customer or merchant to submit evidence:
If action isThe status updates to
BUYER_EVIDENCE WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE
SELLER_EVIDENCE WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE

post.description:
Appeals a dispute, by ID. To appeal a dispute, use the appeal link in the HATEOAS links from the show dispute details response. If this link does not appear, you cannot appeal the dispute. Submit new evidence as a document or notes in the JSON request body. The following rules apply to document file types and sizes:
  • The merchant can upload up to 50 MB of files for a case.
  • Individual files must be smaller than 10 MB.
  • The supported file formats are JPG, GIF, PNG, and PDF.

To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the evidence in the JSON request body. For information about dispute reasons, see dispute reasons.

tags.name: disputes
tags.description: Use the `/disputes` resource to list disputes, create disputes, show dispute details, and partially a dispute. Normally, an agent at PayPal creates disputes but now you can run test cases in the sandbox that create disputes.

tags.name: disputes-actions
tags.description:
Use the `/disputes` resource with a dispute ID and an action to:
  • Accept a claim.
  • Accept an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Acknowledge the return of an item related to a dispute.
  • Settle a dispute.
  • Appeal a dispute.
  • Cancel a dispute.
  • Change the reason for a dispute.
  • Deny an offer to resolve dispute.
  • Escalate a dispute to a claim.
  • Make an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Make an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Provide evidence for a dispute.
  • Provide supporting information for dispute.
  • In the sandbox, update the dispute status.
  • Send a message about a dispute to the other party in the dispute.

tags.name: referred-disputes
tags.description: Use the `/customer/referred-disputes` resource to create a dispute for a referred case that was created by a partner or marketplace, show details for a referred dispute, by ID, notify referred refunds completed to PayPal, notify PayPal about referred dispute adjudication updates, and determine the dispute eligibility for referred disputes.

tags.name: validate-eligibility
tags.description: Use the `/validate-eligibility/` resource to determine whether you can create a case for a transaction.

tags.name: compute-metrics
tags.description: Use the `/compute-metrics` resource to provide metrics for all disputes.

tags.name: validate-referred-dispute-eligibility
tags.description: Use the `/validate-referred-dispute-eligibility` resource to determine whether you can create a referred case for a transaction, by encrypted transaction ID.

tags.name: referred-disputes
tags.description: Use the `/referred-disputes` resource to create a dispute for a referred case that was created by a partner or marketplace, show details for a referred dispute, by ID, notify referred refunds completed to PayPal, notify PayPal about referred dispute adjudication updates, and determine the dispute eligibility for referred disputes.

tags.name: referred-disputes-actions
tags.description: Use the `/referred-disputes` resource with a dispute ID and an action to notify PayPal about adjudication updates for a referred dispute and notify PayPal about a refund for a referred dispute.

tags.name: partner-actions
tags.description: Use the `/disputes/{id}/partner-actions/` resource to show dispute action details and partially update a dispute action.

tags.name: search-suggestions
tags.description: Use the `/search-suggestions` resource to show search suggestions.

tags.name: dispute-events
tags.description: Use the `/dispute-events` resource to send dispute events.

response-dispute_search.json.title: Dispute Search Response
response-dispute_search.json.description: An array of disputes. Includes links that enable you to navigate through the response.

items.description: An array of disputes that match the filter criteria. Sorted in latest to earliest creation time order.

total_items.description: The total number of items. If the request specifies `total_required=true`, appears in the response.

total_pages.description: The total number of pages. If the request specifies `total_required=true`, appears in the response.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

update_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

disputed_transactions.description: An array of transactions for which disputes were created.

disputed_account_activities.description: An array of merchant account activities.

dispute_amount.description: The amount in the transaction that the customer originally disputed. Because customers can sometimes dispute only part of the payment, the disputed amount might be different from the total gross or net amount of the original transaction.

external_reason_code.description: The code that identifies the reason for the credit card chargeback. Each card issuer follows their own standards for defining reason type, code, and its format. For more details about the external reason code, see the card issue site. Available for only unbranded transactions.

messages.description: An array of customer- or merchant-posted messages for the dispute.

buyer_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the customer must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the customer does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the merchant's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

seller_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the merchant must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the merchant does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the customer's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

partner_actions.description: An array of all the actions that are associated to this dispute.

supporting_info.description: An array of all the supporting information that are associated to this dispute.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description:
The date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). Seconds are required while fractional seconds are optional.
Note: The regular expression provides guidance but does not reject all invalid dates.

response-transaction_info.json.title: Transaction Information
response-transaction_info.json.description: The information about the disputed transaction.

buyer_transaction_id.description: The ID, as seen by the customer, for this transaction.

seller_transaction_id.description: The ID, as seen by the merchant, for this transaction.

reference_id.description: The ID, as seen by the partner, for this transaction.

create_time.description: The date and time when the transaction was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

x-enum.description: The items in the transaction are unclaimed. If they are not claimed within 30 days, the funds are returned to the sender.
The transaction is waiting to be processed.
The payment for the transaction was partially refunded.
The payment for the transaction was successfully refunded.
The payment for the transaction was reversed due to a chargeback or other reversal type.

gross_amount.description: The gross amount of the transaction.

invoice_number.description: The ID of the invoice for the payment.

custom.description: A free-text field that is entered by the merchant during checkout.

items.description: An array of items that were purchased as part of the transaction.

seller_protection_eligible.description: Indicates whether the merchant is eligible for protection on the disputed transaction.

seller_protection_type.description: Indicates the type of protection the merchant is eligible on the disputed transaction.

x-enum.description: Merchants are covered under seller protection provided they have responded with valid evidence.
Merchants are eligible for seller protection irrespective of them responding with the proof of shipment/delivery.
Merchants are protected in the subsequent case if an internal case is communicated as resolved in merchant favor.
Merchants who are covered need not respond and paypal takes the loss for all unbranded external unuath chargebacks.
Merchants who are covered need to provide proof of fulfillment and paypal takes the loss(unless paypal contests the case and wins) for all unbranded external unuath chargebacks.
The provisional credit was not applied.
The provisional credit in pending debit.

x-links.title: The sale transaction id of the crypto asset which was used to fulfil the transaction.
The transaction id of Paypal Balance to Savings account

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Money
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The currency and amount for a financial transaction, such as a balance or payment due.

value.description:
The value, which might be:
  • An integer for currencies like `JPY` that are not typically fractional.
  • A decimal fraction for currencies like `TND` that are subdivided into thousandths.
For the required number of decimal places for a currency code, see [Currency Codes](/docs/api/reference/currency-codes/).

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The [three-character ISO-4217 currency code](/docs/api/reference/currency-codes/) that identifies the currency.

response-buyer.json.title: Customer
response-buyer.json.description: The details for the customer who funds the payment. For example, the customer's first name, last name, and email address.

email.description: The email address for the customer's PayPal account.

payer_id.description: The Payer ID of the Buyer.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description:
The internationalized email address.
Note: Up to 64 characters are allowed before and 255 characters are allowed after the @ sign. However, the generally accepted maximum length for an email address is 254 characters. The pattern verifies that an unquoted @ sign exists.

The PayPal payer ID, which is a masked version of the PayPal account number intended for use with third parties. The account number is reversibly encrypted and a proprietary variant of Base32 is used to encode the result.

response-seller.json.title: Merchant
response-seller.json.description: The details for the merchant who receives the funds and fulfills the order. For example, merchant ID, and contact email address.

email.description: The email address for the merchant's PayPal account.

merchant_id.description: The PayPal account ID for the merchant.

response-facilitator.json.title: Facilitator
response-facilitator.json.description: A resource representing a Facilitator/Partner who facilitates a transaction.

response-item_info.json.title: Item Information
response-item_info.json.description: The information for a purchased item in a disputed transaction.

item_id.description: The item ID. If the merchant provides multiple pieces of evidence and the transaction has multiple item IDs, the merchant can use this value to associate a piece of evidence with an item ID.

item_quantity.description: The count of the item in the dispute. Must be a whole number.

partner_transaction_id.description: The ID of the transaction in the partner system. The partner transaction ID is returned at an item level because the partner might show different transactions for different items in the cart.

dispute_amount.description: The amount of the item in the dispute.

notes.description: Any notes provided with the item.

expected_refund.description: The expected refund amount for the item.

response-dispute_reason.json.title: Dispute Reason
response-dispute_reason.json.description: The reason for the item-level dispute. For information about the required information for each dispute reason and associated evidence type, see dispute reasons.

x-enum.description: The customer did not receive the merchandise or service.
The customer reports that the merchandise or service is not as described.
The customer did not authorize purchase of the merchandise or service.
The refund or credit was not processed for the customer.
The customer was charged an incorrect amount.
The customer paid for the transaction through other means.
The customer was being charged for a subscription or a recurring transaction that was canceled.
A problem occurred with the remittance.

response-item_type.json.title: Item Type
response-item_type.json.description: The type of the item which has the issue.

x-enum.description: The digital download has an issue.

product_received_time.description: The date and time when product was delivered.

expected_delivery_time.description: The expected delivery date and time of the product.

expected_delivery_address.description: The address to which the product was expected to be delivered.

delivered_address.description: The address to which the product was delivered.

purchase_url.description: The URL where the customer purchased the product.

response-item_product_sub_reason.json.description: The item level sub-reason for the product issue.

x-enum.description: The product was different from what was expected.
The tracking info was not received.
The product was not available during a store pick up.
The product was delivered to the wrong shipping address.
The customer was not satisfied with the delivered product.
The customer received an item which is not related to the order.
The product was delivered with delay.

response-item_product_category.json.title: Item Product Category
response-item_product_category.json.description: The product category of the item in dispute.

x-enum.description: Home goods, appliances and so on.
Decorative items, ornaments, and so on.
Entertainment goods, such as video games, DVDs, and so on.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Portable Postal Address (Medium-Grained)
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The portable international postal address. Maps to [AddressValidationMetadata](https://github.com/googlei18n/libaddressinput/wiki/AddressValidationMetadata) and HTML 5.1 [Autofilling form controls: the autocomplete attribute](https://www.w3.org/TR/html51/sec-forms.html#autofilling-form-controls-the-autocomplete-attribute).

address_line_1.description: The first line of the address. For example, number or street. For example, `173 Drury Lane`. Required for data entry and compliance and risk checks. Must contain the full address.

address_line_2.description: The second line of the address. For example, suite or apartment number.

address_line_3.description: The third line of the address, if needed. For example, a street complement for Brazil, direction text, such as `next to Walmart`, or a landmark in an Indian address.

admin_area_4.description:
The neighborhood, ward, or district. Smaller than `admin_area_level_3` or `sub_locality`. Value is:
  • The postal sorting code for Guernsey and many French territories, such as French Guiana.
  • The fine-grained administrative levels in China.

admin_area_3.description:
A sub-locality, suburb, neighborhood, or district. Smaller than `admin_area_level_2`. Value is:
  • Brazil. Suburb, bairro, or neighborhood.
  • India. Sub-locality or district. Street name information is not always available but a sub-locality or district can be a very small area.

admin_area_2.description: A city, town, or village. Smaller than `admin_area_level_1`.

admin_area_1.description:
The highest level sub-division in a country, which is usually a province, state, or ISO-3166-2 subdivision. Format for postal delivery. For example, `CA` and not `California`. Value, by country, is:
  • UK. A county.
  • US. A state.
  • Canada. A province.
  • Japan. A prefecture.
  • Switzerland. A kanton.

postal_code.description: The postal code, which is the zip code or equivalent. Typically required for countries with a postal code or an equivalent. See [postal code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_code).

address_details.title: Address Details
address_details.description:
The non-portable additional address details that are sometimes needed for compliance, risk, or other scenarios where fine-grain address information might be needed. Not portable with common third party and open source. Redundant with core fields.
For example, `address_portable.address_line_1` is usually a combination of `address_details.street_number`, `street_name`, and `street_type`.

street_name.description: The street name. Just `Drury` in `Drury Lane`.

street_type.description: The street type. For example, avenue, boulevard, road, or expressway.

delivery_service.description: The delivery service. Post office box, bag number, or post office name.

building_name.description: A named locations that represents the premise. Usually a building name or number or collection of buildings with a common name or number. For example, Craven House.

sub_building.description: The first-order entity below a named building or location that represents the sub-premises. Usually a single building within a collection of buildings with a common name. Can be a flat, story, floor, room, or apartment.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description:
The [two-character ISO 3166-1 code](/docs/api/reference/country-codes/) that identifies the country or region.
Note: The country code for Great Britain is GB and not UK as used in the top-level domain names for that country. Use the `C2` country code for China worldwide for comparable uncontrolled price (CUP) method, bank card, and cross-border transactions.

download_url.description: The URL where the customer downloaded the digital product.

cancelled.description: Indicates whether the item was canceled.

cancellation_time.description: The date and time of the cancellation, in [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

cancelled_by.description: The party which cancelled the order.

cancellation_mode.description: Indicates the mode used for order cancellation.

The item was cancelled through either phone or fax.
The item was cancelled through either email or text message.
The item was cancelled via written communication.
The item was cancelled in person.

policy_url.description: The URL of the Merchant or Marketplace site which have refund or cancellation policy.

response-item_agreed_refund_details.json.title: Agreed Refund Details - item
response-item_agreed_refund_details.json.description: Details of Agreed Refund between customer and merchant.

merchant_agreed_refund_amount.description: The merchant agreed refund amount for the item.

merchant_agreed_refund_time.description: The date and time proposed by merchant to provide the refund, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

response-regulation_info.json.title: Regulation Information
response-regulation_info.json.description: The details for the regulation under which the transaction is covered.

regulation_covered.description: The regulation under which the transaction is covered.

resolution_sla.description: The date and time when the dispute must be resolved, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

For pre-processing, include the `$`, `(`, and `)` characters. The `href` is the key HATEOAS component that links a completed call with a subsequent call.

response-dispute_lifecycle_stage.json.description: The stage in the dispute lifecycle.

x-enum.description:
A customer and merchant interact in an attempt to resolve a dispute without escalation to PayPal. Occurs when the customer:
  • Has not received goods or a service.
  • Reports that the received goods or service are not as described.
  • Needs more details, such as a copy of the transaction or a receipt.

A customer or merchant escalates an inquiry to a claim, which authorizes PayPal to investigate the case and make a determination. Occurs only when the dispute channel is INTERNAL. This stage is a PayPal dispute lifecycle stage and not a credit card or debit card chargeback. All notes that the customer sends in this stage are visible to PayPal agents only. The customer must wait for PayPals response before the customer can take further action. In this stage, PayPal shares dispute details with the merchant, who can complete one of these actions:
  • Accept the claim.
  • Submit evidence to challenge the claim.
  • Make an offer to the customer to resolve the claim.

The first appeal stage for merchants. A merchant can appeal a chargeback if PayPal's decision is not in the merchant's favor. If the merchant does not appeal within the appeal period, PayPal considers the case resolved.

The second appeal stage for merchants. A merchant can appeal a dispute for a second time if the first appeal was denied. If the merchant does not appeal within the appeal period, the case returns to a resolved status in pre-arbitration stage.

This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase and occurs when a merchant is willing to refund a specific amount and requires the customer to return the item. Include the return_shipping_address parameter and the offer_amount parameter in the make offer request.

The merchant must do a refund and then send a replacement item to the customer. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase when a merchant is willing to refund a specific amount and send the replacement item. Include the offer_amount parameter in the make offer request.

The merchant must send a replacement item to the customer with no additional refunds. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase when a merchant is willing to replace the item without any refund. Omit the offer_amount parameter from the make offer request.

description.description: The human-readable description for an issue. The description can change over the lifetime of an API, so clients must not depend on this value.

refund_info.description: The refund details for the dispute.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

disputed_transactions.description: An array of transactions for which disputes were created.

disputed_account_activities.description: An array of merchant account activities.

dispute_amount.description: The amount in the transaction that the customer originally disputed. Because customers can sometimes dispute only part of the payment, the disputed amount might be different from the total gross or net amount of the original transaction.

fee_policy.description: Policy that determines whether the fee needs to be charged, retained or returned while moving the money as part of dispute process.

external_reason_code.description: The code that identifies the reason for the credit card chargeback. Each card issuer follows their own standards for defining reason type, code, and its format. For more details about the external reason code, see the card issue site. Available for only unbranded transactions.

money_movements.description: The Money movement details for the dispute.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: An array of JSON patch objects to apply partial updates to resources.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Patch
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The JSON patch object to apply partial updates to resources.

x-enum.description:
Depending on the target location reference, completes one of these functions:
  • The target location is an array index. Inserts a new value into the array at the specified index.
  • The target location is an object parameter that does not already exist. Adds a new parameter to the object.
  • The target location is an object parameter that does exist. Replaces that parameter's value.
The value parameter defines the value to add. For more information, see 4.1. add.
Removes the value at the target location. For the operation to succeed, the target location must exist. For more information, see 4.2. remove.

Replaces the value at the target location with a new value. The operation object must contain a value parameter that defines the replacement value. For the operation to succeed, the target location must exist. For more information, see 4.3. replace.

Removes the value at a specified location and adds it to the target location. The operation object must contain a from parameter, which is a string that contains a JSON pointer value that references the location in the target document from which to move the value. For the operation to succeed, the from location must exist. For more information, see 4.4. move.

Copies the value at a specified location to the target location. The operation object must contain a from parameter, which is a string that contains a JSON pointer value that references the location in the target document from which to copy the value. For the operation to succeed, the from location must exist. For more information, see 4.5. copy.

Tests that a value at the target location is equal to a specified value. The operation object must contain a value parameter that defines the value to compare to the target location's value. For the operation to succeed, the target location must be equal to the value value. For test, equal indicates that the value at the target location and the value that value defines are of the same JSON type. The data type of the value determines how equality is defined:
TypeConsidered equal if both values
stringsContain the same number of Unicode characters and their code points are byte-by-byte equal.
numbersAre numerically equal.
arraysContain the same number of values, and each value is equal to the value at the corresponding position in the other array, by using these type-specific rules.
objectsContain the same number of parameters, and each parameter is equal to a parameter in the other object, by comparing their keys (as strings) and their values (by using these type-specific rules).
literals (false, true, and null)Are the same. The comparison is a logical comparison. For example, whitespace between the parameter values of an array is not significant. Also, ordering of the serialization of object parameters is not significant.
For more information, see 4.6. test.

path.description: The JSON Pointer to the target document location at which to complete the operation.

value.title: Patch Value
value.description: The value to apply. The remove operation does not require a value.

from.description: The JSON Pointer to the target document location from which to move the value. Required for the move operation.

request-accept_claim.json.description: A request by a merchant to accept a customer's merchandise claim.

The return address for the item.

Required when the customer must return an item to the merchant for the MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED dispute reason, especially if the refund amount is less than the dispute amount.

refund_amount.description:
To accept a customer's claim, the amount that the merchant agrees to refund the customer. The subsequent action depends on the amount:
  • If this amount is less than the customer-requested amount, the dispute updates to require customer acceptance.
  • If this amount is equal to or greater than the customer-requested amount, this amount is automatically refunded to the customer and the dispute closes.

Merchant is accepting customer's claim as the merchant is not able to find sufficient evidence to win this dispute
Merchant is accepting customers claims to follow their internal company policy
This is the default value merchant can use if none of the above reasons apply

response-dispute_eligibility.json.title: Dispute Eligibility Response
response-dispute_eligibility.json.description: The eligible and ineligible disputes with reasons.

seller_transaction_id.description: The seller transaction ID that is associated with the encrypted transaction ID that is passed in the request. The dispute creation is allowed on the buyer transaction ID, which must be passed in the create dispute call.

buyer_transaction_id.description: The buyer transaction ID that is associated with the `encrypted_transaction_id` passed in the request.

eligible_dispute_reasons.description: An array of the eligible disputes with reasons.

ineligible_dispute_reasons.description: An array of the ineligible disputes with ineligibility reasons.

allowable_life_cycle.title: Allowable Lifecycle
allowable_life_cycle.description: The details about the allowable lifecycle stage and the reason why it is allowed.

stage.description: The stage in the dispute life cycle where the dispute creation is allowed.

x-enum.description: Dispute is allowed in the INQUIRY lifecycle stage.
Dispute is allowed in the CHARGEBACK lifecycle stage.

reason.description: The reason why dispute creation is allowed in this lifecycle stage. Value is `SELLER_OPTED_OUT_OF_DISPUTE`, `LOCKED_SELLER`, `RESTRICTED_SELLER`, or `DISPUTE_DISABLED_PARTNER`.

response-ineligible_dispute_reason.json.title: Ineligible Dispute Reason
response-ineligible_dispute_reason.json.description: The ineligible dispute with the reason for ineligibility.

ineligibility_reason.description: The reason that the dispute cannot be created.

request-eligibility_request.json.title: Eligibility Request
request-eligibility_request.json.description: For a new case, lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons. For an existing dispute, lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons; the eligible reasons are the ones that the customer can use to update the dispute. To check the eligibility of case creation, specify the encrypted transaction ID. To check the eligibility of dispute reason modification, specify the dispute ID.

encrypted_transaction_id.description: The encrypted transaction ID. The response lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons.

dispute_id.description: The ID of the dispute. The response lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons. The customer can use the eligible reasons to update the dispute.

buyer_note.description: Customer provided description of the issue.

metrics.description: An array of dimension and measurement metrics for disputes.

key.description: The group name for a dimension.

count.description: The count of items in a group.

amount.description: An array of the sums of amounts for each currency.

items.description: The sum of amounts for each currency.

dimension.description: The dimension for which to list metrics.

x-enum.description: Shows the results of metrics by the STATUS dimension. For example, if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different status.
Shows the results of metrics by the REASON dimension. For example if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different reason.
Shows the results of metrics by the OUTCOME dimension. For example if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different outcome.
Shows the results of metrics by the DISPUTE_STATE dimension. For example if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different dispute states.

measure.description: The measure for the dimension for which to list metrics.

x-enum.description: Shows the count of disputes by the dimension in the request.
Shows the sum of dispute amount of the disputes by the dimension in the request.
Shows the sum of transaction amount of associated disputes by the dimension in the request.
Shows the sum of refund amount of associated disputes by the dimension in the request.

request-filter.json.title: Filter
request-filter.json.description: A set of filters that you can use to filter the disputes in the response.

email.description: Filters the disputes in the response by an email.

name.description: Filters the disputes in the response by the full name of a counter party.

reasons.description: Filters the disputes in the response by one or more reasons. Use a comma to separate multiple reasons. The response lists disputes that belong to any of the specified reasons.

statuses.description: Filters the disputes in the response by one or more statuses. Use a comma to separate multiple statuses. The response lists disputes with any of the specified statuses.

create_time_before.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were created before this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

create_time_after.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were created after this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

update_time_before.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were updated before this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

update_time_after.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were updated after this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

response_due_date_before.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that are due before this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

response_due_date_after.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that are due after this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

dispute_amount_gte.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that have a dispute amount that is greater than or equal to this amount.

dispute_amount_lte.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that have a dispute amount that is less than or equal to this amount.

response-suggestion_response.json.title: Dispute Search Suggestion Response
response-suggestion_response.json.description: Arrays of auto-complete and DidYouMean values. Includes links that enable you to navigate through the response.

suggestions.description: An array of auto complete values for the given search_text if present.

items.description: An auto complete value for the given search text.

corrected_search_text.description: The possible DidYouMean value if there are no suggestions for given search_text.

referred-referred_eligibility_response.j.title: Dispute Eligibility Response
referred-referred_eligibility_response.j.description: The eligible and ineligible disputes with reasons. Disputes and refund information are returned, if applicable.

eligible.description: Indicates whether the transaction can be disputed.

allowable_life_cycle.description: The details about the allowable life cycle stage and the reason why it is allowed.

x-enum.description: A customer and merchant interact in an attempt to resolve a dispute without escalation to PayPal. Occurs when a customer has not received goods or a service, the goods or service are not as described, or the customer needs additional details on a transaction, such as a copy of the transaction or a receipt

This stage occurs when a customer or merchant escalates an inquiry to a claim. Claims give PayPal the authority to investigate the case and determine an outcome if the dispute channel is `INTERNAL`. This state is a PayPal dispute lifecycle stage and is not to be interpreted as a credit card or debit card charge back

ineligibility_reason.description: The reason that the dispute could not be created.

x-enum.description: The item category passed in is not disputable.
Dispute already exists for a Transaction.

existing_disputes.description: An array of details about the disputes on the transaction.

existing_refunds.description: An array of details about the refunds on the disputed transaction, if applicable.

id.description: The ID of the PayPal-side dispute.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

update_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

x-enum.description: The customer did not receive the merchandise or service.
The customer reports that the merchandise or service is not as described.
The customer did not authorize purchase of the merchandise or service.
The refund or credit was not processed for the customer.
The customer was charged an incorrect amount.
The customer paid for the transaction through other means.
The customer was being charged for a subscription or a recurring transaction that was canceled.
A problem occurred with the remittance.
This represents an internal PayPal dispute scenario. You need to contact PayPal for more information in this dispute.

id.description: The ID of the PayPal refund transaction.

x-enum.description: The refund transaction is on hold.
The refund transaction is waiting to be processed.
The refund transaction is getting processed.
The payment for the transaction was partially refunded.
The payment for the transaction was successfully refunded.
The payment for the refund transaction was reversed.
The payment for the transaction was canceled.
The refund transaction is in some unknown status.

gross_amount.description: The gross amount of the transaction.

create_time.description: The date and time when the refund transaction was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

referred-referred_eligibility_request.js.description: For a new third-party case, lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons. The customer can use the eligible reasons to create a dispute. To check the eligibility of case creation, specify the encrypted transaction ID.

referred-referred_eligibility_request_it.title: Eligibility Request Items
referred-referred_eligibility_request_it.description: Information about the items in the transaction.

referred-referred_item_category.json.description: The category of the item in dispute.

Entertainment goods, such as video games, DVDs, and so on.
Services, such as installation, repair, and so on.
Non-physical objects, such as online games.
Tickets for events, such as sports, concerts, and so on.

referred-referred_dispute_flow.json.description: The flow ID for the dispute being created.

referred-referred_extensions.json.description: The extended properties for the dispute. Includes additional information for a dispute category, such as billing disputes, the original transaction ID, correct amount, and so on.

reason.description: The reason for the temporary hold on the dispute.

reason.description: The reason for recoup for the dispute.

referred-referred_transaction.json.description: The transaction for which to create a case.

id.description: The ID of the PayPal transaction.

items.description: An array of items in the transaction in the dispute.

The transaction is waiting to be processed.
The payment for the transaction was partially refunded.
The payment for the transaction was successfully refunded.
The payment for the transaction was reversed due to a chargeback or another type of reversal.
The payment for the transaction was canceled.

referred-referred_item_info.json.description: The information for a purchased item in a disputed transaction.

referred-referred_dispute_reason.json.description: The reason for the item-level dispute. For information about the required information for each dispute reason and associated evidence type, see dispute reasons.

x-enum.description: The customer did not receive the merchandise or service.
The customer reports that the merchandise or service is not as described.
The order is incomplete. It has missing parts or an incorrect quantity.
The item is materially different. It is a different item, the wrong size or model,the wrong color, or used instead of new.

referred-reference_dispute.json.description: The details about the partner dispute.

referred-referred_disputes.json.description: An array of disputes. Includes links that enable you to navigate through the response.

total_pages.description: The total number of pages in the response.

dispute_id.description: The ID of the PayPal-side dispute.

reference_disputes.description: The details about the partner disputes.

dispute_amount.description: The amount in the transaction that the customer originally disputed. Because customers can sometimes dispute only part of the payment, the disputed amount might be different from the total gross or net amount of the original transaction.

x-enum.description: A third-party claim. The dispute requires custom handling.
A third-party dispute. The dispute does not require any special handling. Defaults to default procedures.

id.description: The ID of the PayPal-side dispute.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

dispute_flow.description: The flow ID for the dispute being created.

reference_disputes.description: The details about the partner disputes.

transaction.description: The details about the transactions in the referred dispute.

evidences.description: The partner-submitted evidence documents, such as tracking information.

messages.description: An array of customer- or merchant-posted messages.

referred-referred_refund_info.json.description: The payout details for the referred dispute.

event-dispute_cloud_event.json.title: The Cloudevent envelope
event-dispute_cloud_event.json.description: The Cloudevent envelope as specified in https://cloudevents.io/.

specversion.description: The CloudEvent specification version that this event uses, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#specversion).

datacontenttype.description: The Content type of the data attribute value, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#datacontenttype).

x-enum.description: The supported content type of the dispute event.

data.description: The event payload, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#event-data).

id.description: The identifier of the event, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#id).

time.description: The timestamp of the event occurrence, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#time).

dataschema.description: The schema that data adheres to, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#dataschema).

subject.description: The subject of the event, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#subject).

type.description:
The value describing the type of event related to the originating occurrence, as defined in the [CloudEvents Specification](https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#type). Supported type :
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.created` - The dispute with the specified `dispute_id` has been created.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.reason-changed` - The `reason` of the dispute has been changed
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.cancelled` - The dispute has been cancelled.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.claim-accepted` - The merchant has accepted the claim.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.offer-made` - The merchant has made an offer.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.offer-accepted` - The customer has accepted the offer.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.offer-denied` - The customer / merchant has provided a supporting info.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.escalated` - The dispute has been escalated.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.message-sent` - The customer / merchant has posted a message.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.item-return-acknowledged` - The merchant has acknowledged the item returned.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.evidence-provided` - The customer / merchant has provided an evidence.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.supporting-info-provided` - The customer / merchant has provided supporting information.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.appealed` - The customer / merchant has appealed the adjudication.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.evidence-requested` - The customer / merchant has been requested the evidence.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.adjudicated` - The dispute has been adjudicated.
`com.paypal.customer.disputes.resolved` - The dispute has been resolved.

source.description: The event source, as defined in https://github.com/cloudevents/spec/blob/v1.0/spec.md#source-1.

amount.description: The amount associated with the event.

notes.description: The notes associated with the event.

disputed_transactions.description: An array of transactions for which disputes were created.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute event was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

external_reason_code.description: The code that identifies the reason for the credit card chargeback. Each card issuer follows their own standards for defining reason type, code, and its format. For more details about the external reason code, see the card issue site. Available for only unbranded transactions.

response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the response needs to be available for the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.
